title: Chris Cairns trial: Lou Vincent’s ex-wife gives stunning testimony in London court
text:
CHRIS Cairns threatened teammates they would “never play cricket again” unless they joined him in a match fixing scheme, according to evidence heard in a London court.
The ongoing trial of the former New Zealand all-rounder has already produced some astonishing testimony from Cairns’ former teammates, but on Monday it was the turn of disgraced batsman Lou Vincent’s ex-wife, Eleanor Riley, to take the stand.
Riley, who divorced from Vincent in 2012, recounted a conversation the pair had with Cairns and his wife Mel in a restaurant near Manchester in 2008, when the two men were playing county cricket in England.
SUMMARY: WHAT’S BEEN SAID IN CAIRNS TRIAL SO FAR
Lou Vincent (R) departs Southwark Crown Court with his current partner Susie. Source: Getty Images
Riley says she was worried at the time that her husband would be caught match-fixing as there were many players involved and Vincent “had a tendency to talk to anyone who listened.”
According to Riley, Cairns assured her there was no way they would get caught because “everyone was doing it in India”.
Cairns’ lawyer, Orlando Pownall QC, questioned whether Riley might have ulterior motives for testifying against his client.
However Riley said she and Vincent did not part on good terms and that “I certainly wouldn’t come to a perjury trial to lie”.
She also counteracted suggestions that her memory was hazy due to alcohol by saying, “When I’ve had a large meal it doesn’t matter how much I drink, I’m as clear as a bell.”
Riley didn’t let her ex-husband off the hook during her testimony, admitting Vincent “hated Chris Cairns” because he believed he owed him money.
Former New Zealand cricketer Chris Cairns. Source: AP
She also said Vincent gave his explosive evidence in the hope it would allow him to escape charges he himself faced for match fixing.
In her evidence, Riley detailed the first occasion Vincent admitted to her that he had been involved in match fixing during the now-defunct Indian Cricket League.
“He was crying,” Riley said. “He told me that he had lied, that he had taken the money for the match-fixing.
“He told me that he had stuffed a game up. He just hadn’t played how he was supposed to play.
“He said that he was working with Chris - Chris Cairns.”
Last week, Vincent, together with current New Zealand captain Brendon McCullum and bowling coach Shane Bond, gave testimony that they either knew or believed Cairns had been involved in match fixing.
Former Australia captain Ricky Ponting is due to give evidence in the trial soon.
